TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: naizua zazua ti sa Kului, a naputsekeł tua vuluvulung, aya a tjautsikel.
naizoa zazoa ti sa Koloi, a napocekelj toa volovolong, aya a tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: Once there was a person called Kului who was married to a hundred-pace snake, according to the story.

S.FORM: saka nu qezemezemetj tsautsau, saka nu maqadaw qatjuvi.
saka no qezemezemetj caocao, saka no maqadaw qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: At night it was human, and in the day it was a snake.

S.FORM: inika tja łengłengan a zuma.
inika tja ljengljengan a zoma.
S.TRANSL: The rest of us couldn’t see it.

S.FORM: izuazua tua vakar a pinaseleman tua itung.
izoazoa toa vakar a pinaseleman toa itong.
S.TRANSL: It was in a bamboo basket hidden by clothes.

S.FORM: saka inika ui tja patsunan ni Kului.
saka inika oi tja paconan ni Koloi.
S.TRANSL: Kului didn’t allow us to look at it.

S.FORM: manu "ki anema izua?" aya ti sa Ulung a kaka.
mano "ki anema izoa?" aya ti sa Ulong a kaka.
S.TRANSL: “What’s in there?” said her sibling Ulung.

S.FORM: "aku sikaqiłi aya tja qayamen?"
"ako sikaqilji aya tja qayamen?"
S.TRANSL: “Why are we not allowed to see it?”

S.FORM: "sa-u satjatjanu," ayain ti Kului ni sa Ulung.
"sa-o satjatjano," ayain ti Koloi ni sa Ulong.
S.TRANSL: “Go to the spring for water,” said Ulung to Kului.

S.FORM: ka qayamen, manu qatjuvi a vuluvulung.
ka qayamen, mano qatjovi a volovolong.
S.TRANSL: When (s)he had a look, it was a hundred-pace snake.

S.FORM: saka "aku ka qayamen aken?" aya, sa vaik anga zazua malipat (tua) valuku a i navał.
saka "ako ka qayamen aken?" aya, sa vaik anga zazoa malipat (toa) valoko a i navalj.
S.TRANSL: “Why are you looking at me?” it said, and disappeared down the hole in the south.

S.FORM: ka mangtjez ti Kului kasi tjatjan, ka qayamen a vakar, nekanga a qatjuvi.
ka mangtjez ti Koloi kasi tjatjan, ka qayamen a vakar, nekanga a qatjovi.
S.TRANSL: When Kului came back from the spring and looked at the basket, there was no snake.

S.FORM: "inu anga?" aya ti Kului.
"ino anga?" aya ti Koloi.
"aku su pinivakar a qatjuvi?" aya ti sa Ulung, sa kagarangi ti Kului.
"ako so pinivakar a qatjovi?" aya ti sa Ulong, sa kagarangi ti Koloi.
S.TRANSL: “Why did you put a snake in the basket?” said Ulung, and scolded Kului.

S.FORM: manu "ku zukatj azua," aya ti sa Kului.
mano "ko zokatj azoa," aya ti sa Koloi.
"ki maya nu ranaven tu vaik amen, ka nu qayamen.
"ki maya no ranaven to vaik amen, ka no qayamen.
S.TRANSL: “I suppose you deliberately made us go, when you had a look.

S.FORM: łakua ki tja kudain? vaik aken a kitsiur," aya.
ljakoa ki tja kodain? vaik aken a kicior," aya.
S.TRANSL: What are we to do? I’m going off with him,” she said.

S.FORM: saka maulaw anga, aya a tjautsikel.
saka maolaw anga, aya a tjaocikel.
S.TRANSL: And she disappeared, according to the story.
